rComments: The prof is nice but the lectures were poorly orgranized. SMC228 is really easy.

3 hour lectures that could be condensed to 30 minutes. He straight up does not teach. He wastes time on "exercises" that make you feel like you're in middle school. People giving positive reviews appreciate the easiness of some assignments and the triviality of the "fun" we have in class. He's a sweet man, but also the reason I dropped my BMS major

Said at the beginning of the year that we'd have 1-2 readings per week, not that long, but trust me, they were long. He's very nice, says hello to everyone before the lecture starts, and even if you miss a class, just do the readings or you can go back to the lecture slides he will have posted. Overall the classes were alright.
I think his lectures are fun. He tried to make the material easier. You could learn a lot in his course.

I took his SMC228 before, he asked us the same thing but at that time, he said you can put whatever pic you like. Because he doesn't like the grey profile image. And now with SMC219, he actually took screenshots of students who put image other than themselve onto lectureslide to show those student are ordinary. He just do this to make fun of people

teacherRatingTags: ['Tough grader', "Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Get ready to read']

rComments: I learned nothing in this class because out of the 12 lectures, we were only barely given a lecture on 6. He did not teach us anything and expected us to memorize words from readings for fill in the blanks which is impossible and ridiculously hard. Would not recommend.
Paolo Granata is the nicest professor you will get. He is always understanding of student situations and helped me in a very difficult time to hate U of T less.

While very enthusiastic the lectures and readings were really disorganized. Tried to make some creative projects that ended up costing a lot of money. None of the material covered in lecture or reading were challenging in any way. Very highschool-like. Every lecture I felt like there was nothing new to be learned.

Paolo is amazing! He is such a sweet prof and clearly values creativity! I have taken 2 classes with him (the other being SMC229) and no essays for either of them; the assignments are all creative! The tests are easy - always multiple choice. BUT, you need to do the readings to do well on the midterm and final!

This class was poorly organized. Assignments were high school level, and there were LOTS. The lectures themselves were useless, the information presented was basically a biography of the "theorist" we were discussing that week. This class has very little to do with media, culture, and essentially nothing to do with religion.

He's a good guy and an OK prof, I actually enjoyed his out-of-the-box creative assignments, i'd take them any day over an essay. Lectures are long and he tries his best to liven them up. Big issue is that assignments are hella expensive, buying all the supplies and stuff are expensive so get ready to spend. Otherwise, easy class and easy readings.
teacherRatingTags: ['Lecture heavy', 'Clear grading criteria', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Tries to make it fun with games and music but the material is so dry it's hard to do. He often ends up steamrolling material for an hour. The assignments are a bit inane (but easy) and cost a lot of money to produce (expect to spend money on supplies and books to give away). The tests are difficult - get ready to memorize.

Bless Paolo! An actual prof at U of T that doesn't give the most standard and boring assignments. He values creativity and puts a lot of real life skills into his classes. Do the readings for exams. He is a kind soul.

Attendance is a big part of evaluations but he doesn't take attendance. He values creativity and hands-on projects, it's really easy to do well in his classes since he loves individuality and hasn't been polluted by the grade deflation culture at UofT yet LOL LOVE HIM

Professor Granata is new to U of T, but he's already left a great impact in BMS. He explores a nice balance of historical and and modern approaches to media studies. The mid-term and final exam are heavily graded on readings - do not skip readings. His lectures are fun/engaging, and opportunities for creativity is refreshing at a school like U of T
